title: 114_hr2003
content: The Act is titled the "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" and pertains to the distribution of death information by the Social Security Administration. The "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" amends Section 205(r) of the Social Security Act to require the Commissioner of Social Security to transmit information on deceased individuals to ensure completeness, timeliness, and accuracy, with safeguards to protect the information. The "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" requires the Commissioner of Social Security to share information on deceased individuals with federal or state agencies to prevent unauthorized use or disclosure, including through the Do Not Pay system. Agencies must reimburse the Commissioner for associated costs. The Commissioner of Social Security is required to share information on deceased individuals with federal agencies for the Do Not Pay system, ensuring it does not conflict with their duties. This cooperation allows agencies to prevent unauthorized use of deceased individuals' information. The Commissioner of Social Security may disclose personally identifiable information for various purposes, including ensuring proper payments under federal programs, tax administration, debt collection, and use by federal policing agencies for crime prevention and investigation. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with States for specific purposes, such as state-funded programs or retirement systems, as long as certain requirements are met. This information can also be used for the administration of benefit pension plans. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with States for specific purposes, subject to safeguards, for statistical and research activities by Federal and State agencies. Amendments made by this subsection will be repealed after 5 years. The subsections of section 205(r) of the Social Security Act are repealed and restored, while amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code regarding sharing information on deceased individuals by the Commissioner of Social Security. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for Federal agencies, analyzing accuracy, interoperability, accessibility, and cost. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for Federal agencies, analyzing accuracy, security, reliability, and potential alternate sources compared to data from the Commissioner of Social Security. A report will be submitted to Congress within 4 years, including a recommendation on extending agency access to Social Security death data. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for Federal agencies, analyzing accuracy, security, reliability, and potential alternate sources compared to data from the Commissioner of Social Security. A report will be submitted to Congress within 4 years, including a recommendation on extending agency access to Social Security death data beyond the specified repeal date. SEC. 7. IMPROVING THE USE OF DEATH DATA BY GOVERNMENT AGENCIES. The Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 is amended to enhance government agencies' utilization of death data. The Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance to agencies on improving data matching with death databases for beneficiaries and annuity recipients within 6 months of the enactment of this section. The Office of Management and Budget will develop a plan to assist states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations in providing death records electronically to the Federal Government within 1 year of the enactment of this section. This includes recommendations to Congress for any necessary statutory changes or financial assistance. The plan will improve data matching for payments to deceased individuals by ensuring electronic provision of records by States, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations. Recommendations for funding may be included. A report to Congress is required within 270 days of enactment, detailing the plan's implementation. The plan aims to enhance data matching for deceased individuals receiving federally funded benefits through improved collaboration with tribal organizations. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must submit annual reports to Congress on the implementation of this initiative. Definitions for 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' are provided in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The plan focuses on improving the accuracy and completeness of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration. The Commissioner of Social Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, must submit a plan to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The plan aims to ensure the accuracy and completeness of death data, including individuals not receiving benefits under the Social Security Act. It includes procedures for identifying extremely elderly individuals still alive according to records and improving policies for identification. Improved policies and procedures are needed to correct erroneous records in the Numerical Identification System and death data. This includes identifying individuals incorrectly listed as dead or alive, and allowing individuals or survivors to report errors. Statistical analysis of death data will be used to estimate the number of incorrect records. The Commissioner of Social Security will implement a plan within 2 years of the enactment of the Act. Recommendations for legislation will be made, and an estimate of erroneous records will be determined.
